body: I'm happy to take a look at this.

Hi @yoav-lavi after looking into this I'm not sure if this is an actual bug. It seems like when there's certain errors in Webpack they're deliberately not thrown and instead just returned attached to the result, so compiling can still continue. What are your thoughts? @sokra @timse?

Hey @cacheflow, this makes sense in a certain type of usage, although the only alternative to this (if say you need to stop on an error) would be using `bail`, which exits the process (even if Webpack is just being used as a module) rather than throwing the error. The expected result (IMO) would be `bail` throwing errors when Webpack is used as a module, or adding a different flag to do so.

I have a branch that captures errors and passes them to a callback and throws them.. 

I think it makes sense to possibly pass a flag or use the presence of bail so Webpack knows to throw errors or swallow them.

issue.title: fix(Compiler): Promisifed webpack returns errors as a return value

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
**What kind of change does this PR introduce?**

  When Webpack is promisified any compilation error is swallowed and returned in the stats response and thus won't bubble up to the catch block. This adds an additional check for compilation errors and if the configuration object has `bail: true`. If they're both present then any compilation error is thrown and thus bubbles up and allows catch to capture it. 

- [x] Fix

**Did you add tests for your changes?**

- [x] Yes

**Does this PR introduce a breaking change?**

- [x] No

**What needs to be documented once your changes are merged?**

- Fixes #8298

Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.
